PM11:07am

For the past 25 years, we have at this time of year published 10 possible ways in which our central views (and often the consensus) could be surprised. Below we highlight the factors we think could surprise this year, together with our core views.

brace yourself

Braced

11:08 am

BE11:09am

Uh, no.

PM11:09am

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Let's see if there are any surprises in the rest of thepotential surprises

PM11:10am

EURUSD hits 0.90, before strengthening to end the year at 1.20. Core view: Credit Suisse's house view sees the euro declining to 1.03 on a three-month view and down to 1.00 on a 12-month view.
■ Chinese GDP growth slows to 5% and with it the RmB weakens to 8. Core view: 6.8% GDP growth in 2017 and the RmB weakens to 7.33 at year-end.
■ A Le Pen victory in France's presidential election. Core view: Francois Fillon becomes president.
■ European defensives outperform by 15%. Core view: we are a small underweight of defensives, though we did add to them in our Outlook.
■ President Trump's policies disappoint the market. Core view: corporate taxes will be cut, inflation expectations rise and protectionist policies toned down.
■ The oil price hits $75pb by end 2017. Core view: The oil price will rise to $62 by the end of the year.
■ The Nikkei rises to 25,000. Core view: we have a mid-year target for the Nikkei of 20,500.
■ The European pharma sector underperforms by another 10%. Core view: we are overweight pharma and believe it can outperform modestly from Q2 this year.
■ US 10-year Treasury yields hit 4%. Core view: CS US rates strategists have a 3% year-end target.

PM11:16am

BE11:17am

Here comes JP Morgan.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Smurfit Kappa today announced €60/t price increases for white and brown kraftliner across Europe from 1 March. This follows €60/t hike announcements over the last few weeks by recycled
containerboard (RCB) producers. Although concerns remain, in our view (significant RCB capacity due in 2017 & 18, potential for product redirection by Stora from exports to domestic, possible
Turkish anti-dumping tariffs), demand on the ground appears to be stronger than expected and momentum for a kraftliner hike by Europe’s major producers (including Mondi) appears to be building. If Mondi was to achieve a €60/t hike in line with Smurfit’s announcement, this would result in additional EBIT of ~€65m in FY17e (JPMe) and increase JPMe FY17 EPS ~7% by our estimates. Mondi’s share price in EUR is + ~7% since 11 Jan indicating market expectations of at least some hiking success. There could be room for more, in our view, if hikes are actually successful given Mondi’s tendency to experience a PE rerating during kraftliner price up-cycles. On the other hand, failure would likely bring about disappointment given the level of expectations that appears to be baked in. While demand looks strong and momentum appears to be building, supply risks lead us to remain cautious for now, thus we leave forecasts unchanged for the time being while noting overall balance of risk to our estimates appears to be to the upside for FY17e.

BE11:18am

You'll want to know about German unbleached sack kraft paper as well, I figure.

PM11:18am

I certainly do

11:18 am
BE11:18am

German unbleached sack kraft paper has gained €40/t, per RISI’s latest pricing update. Mondi in September 2016 announced €60/t in Europe thus it appears two-thirds of the announced hike has been successful in Europe. While positive for Mondi, this is in line with our expectations and has been included in our FY17 estimates. We await further updates from Mondi on sack kraft export prices in its Feb results but remain comfortable with our overall forecasts for sack kraft paper at this juncture.

BE11:25am

BE11:25am

Inflation getting the blame from the domestic view, mostly.

BE11:26am

Martin Beck, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, comments:

11:26 am
BE11:26am

(yes, this is the first email I could find. I'm a bit unprepared today.)

BE11:26am

“Given the strength of the retail sector in the first two months of Q4, some easing in volume growth was to be expected in December. But a 1.9% drop in sales volumes was well in excess of the consensus expectation of a 0.1% decline and represented the biggest monthly fall since May 2011. All of the main retail sectors saw a monthly drop in sales volumes, with particularly sizeable drops in sales of clothing, footwear and household goods.

“Overall Q4 still delivered a rise in sales volumes of 1.2%, well above the average quarterly rise of 0.5% since the end the last recession. Moreover, sales growth of 4.8% in 2016 was the strongest since 2004.

“However, December’s data delivered some unpleasant omens for this year. Annual shop price inflation accelerated from 0.1% in November to 0.9%, the fastest since the end of 2013 and contrasting with a 3.2% fall in December 2015. So the squeeze on households’ real incomes is gradually tightening, implying a tough 2017 for retailers.”

BE11:27am

........ meanwhile, Exane has a big note out on the supermarkets.

11:27 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 199.35, down 3.25 (-1.60%), High: 200.60, Low: 197.70, Volume: 15.36m
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 263.95, down 4.05 (-1.51%), High: 266.60, Low: 263.50, Volume: 2.89m
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 240.40, down 0.7 (-0.29%), High: 241.60, Low: 239.60, Volume: 3.40m
11:27 am
PM11:28am

What's their argument?

BE11:28am

Tesco goes down to "underperform". The argument, in short, is deterioration from a not-that-good starting point.

BE11:28am

Cutting Tesco to Underperform, Sainsbury’s to Neutral leaves us with no Buys in the UK ‘Less bad’ was a potent theme in 2016; with expectations low and the stars better aligned, Morrisons and Tesco were the top performers. 2017 however is a different story. Expectations are high, there’s cost inflation, and the possibility ASDA improves. The long-term labour market and population impact of Brexit could be bad too. From ‘less bad’, we think the UK outlook is worse and see Tesco’s shares (cut to Underperform, TP 175p from 200p) as the most exposed. We also cut Sainsbury’s to Neutral given the sector risks and limited upside to our unchanged 255p TP.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

On a premium multiple, the risks at Tesco outweigh the rewards
Trading at c17x CY2017 EV/EBIT, expectations are high for Tesco. The group has communicated a 2019/20 EBIT margin ambition (3.5-4.0%) and the shares look to have priced it. Food retail history teaches us however that margin readily adjusts down but the path to recovery is long and rarely straight line. We’d also remind that Tesco is largely a big box operator that is still about 2x the size of its nearest competitor. Consistently growing volume will be a challenge and if volumes go negative as seems quite possible, the de-rating could be sharp.

BE11:29am

Risks are increasing that the food retailers will absorb some cost inflation Our central scenario is that a rise in input prices is passed through to the shopper, but the risk of that not happening is increasing. In targeting a margin, Tesco has signalled its intention which has to be good news – it won’t get there by swallowing supplier increases. The discounters have also nudged up some prices. However, given ‘farm to fork’ is 6-9 months and the Brexit currency shock was 7 months ago, pass through could be far from smooth.

BE11:29am

ASDA may be less of a whipping boy and discounters / online with continue to grow ASDA’s recovery will take time and we don’t subscribe to a view it will dramatically cut prices. But we doubt the group will lose another percentage point of market share (from c16.5% to c15.5% in 2016). With the discounters still taking share (albeit at a slower rate) together with online, and minimum wage rises coming through, the pressure is still on the industry.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Increasingly, Asda has become the cthulhu of the supermarkets.

BE11:30am

We keep waiting for the giant to stir from the deep, talking in doomy terms about when it does.

PM11:30am

* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cthulhu

11:30 am

..... One day, I guess.

11:32 am
PM11:33am

BE11:33am

BE11:33am

11:34 am
BE11:34am

I think they're shop.

BE11:34am

(Though haven't checked that.)

BE11:34am

We expect in-line results in March. 2018 EBITDA is reduced 3%, a 6% cut to EPS due to the leverage. We increase our net debt expectation by £18m to £2,676m, but expect the pension deficit to have fallen. Estimates do not assume further increases in IPT. Free Cash Flow for equity a little lower but within the £150-200m range in FY 2018. At Roadside, we expect progress on new customer additions, but retention will flatten. We expect paid personal members, a key data point, to increase, albeit modestly. New product areas are continuing to develop well. We see industry risks in Roadside as overstated and break-downs are actually increasing. The IT transformation is progressing well. At Insurance, policies are falling but premiums are increasing. TP reduced from 375p to 340p due to low earnings and higher debt.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

We are maintaining our FY 2017 EBITDA of £412m, representing -0.6% growth on FY 16 EBITDA of £415m. We expect 3.8% growth at Roadside Assistance, with EBITDA of £375m in FY 17 (vs. £361m in FY 16). However, this is off-set by Insurance Services where we expect FY 17 EBITDA of £71.4m (vs. £78m in FY 16) and Driving Services where we expect FY 17 EBITDA of £18.5m (vs. £19m in FY 16). We expect a £41m exceptional charge including £15m in respect of redundancies and £3m of IT double-running costs. The £10m of provision for refunds announced in H1 seems adequate. We assume £77m of disposal gains for Ireland to be reported in discontinued operations. It is most likely that the NBV of the legacy systems will be written off as a non-cash exceptional in FY 2018, since they will still be used until July 2018, however there is no estimate at this time of how much this will be. We expect a 53% weighting of EBITDA to H2 (£212m) and a 56% weighting of EPS to H2 (12.5p) giving FY 17 EPS of 22.4p and assume FY 17 DPS of 9.5p. BEPS is now irrelevant given the disposal of Ireland and will not impact The AA. We expect a trading statement on 8th Feb.

BE11:35am

At the time of the refinancing we reduced 2018 EBITDA by £7m to offset the interest gain of the re-fi, leaving headline estimates unchanged. At Personal Membership we now reduce the Personal Member growth for 2018 from 2% to 0.5% as retention flattens, but keep APRU growth at 2% despite the increase in IPT and the fact that revenues are stated net of IPT. We reduce 2018 Roadside Assistance EBITDA margin from 50.7% to 50.0%, principally due to greater use of the service, which validates the model but results in higher operating costs. We therefore reduce Roadside EBITDA from £393m to £383m in FY 18. At Insurance Services we reduce the EBITDA margin from 56.0% to 54.5% as the Bank of Ireland JV increases revenues but not profits, as the products take 2-3 years to pay back. These factors combine to reduce Group EBITDA 3% to £414m and EPS by 6% due to the leverage. These estimates assume no impact from further IPT changes. We also assume £10m of exceptionals in FY 18 as there is more restructuring to come.

BE11:35am

There's a lot more there. It's a very long note. But that gives the gist of it.

PM11:38am

We are closing our short in FCA. In essence, the tailwinds from better demand dynamics ahead outstrip our supply and structural concerns. The stock has rallied +35% post the US election, something CEO Marchionne called a “gamechanger”. While there are many potential policy moving parts, the one real metric that counts for us is the impact on US consumer confidence (which is in break-out mode post-election) since the profit pool for FCA is US SUVs and trucks. Tax cuts on top of real wage growth and still low credit spreads are powerful. We are more skeptical about the well-known mix shift of production from cars to trucks over the next 2-3 years. This sounds very sensible on paper, but not if supply outstrips demand, pricing power won’t hold to the extent it has so far (incentives have largely risen in-line with ASPs) made possible by low interest rates. That is unlikely to matter in the short term, since demand can pick-up more quickly than capacity expansion if the US consumer remains bullish.

What is more, in our Trump tax policy thinking, we could see a tax benefit from the full offset of capex up front. The capital intensive auto sector would benefit, so would its suppliers, but also the buyers of the company’s light trucks. This would create a second leg of demand, i.e. commercial, in addition to what we are currently seeing from consumers seven years after the bottom of the cycle. FCA relies on working capital inflows to fund growth (accounts payable growth far outstrips receivables and inventory growth over the last five years) so end demand growth is doubly important for FCF which has been distinctly lacking for many years.

BE11:41am

PM11:41am

11:41 am

BE11:42am

PM11:42am

11:42 am
PM11:42am

https://www.ft.com/search?q=Immunicorn

BE11:42am

I'm claiming it as my coinage. One that's totally failed to gain wider acceptance, but I'm sticking with it.

BE11:43am

So anyway, this might be bad news for AZN, though the readthrough's far from perfect.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Which means it might also be good news. Basically, BMS is continuing 1st line lung studies, so there might not be a safety readthrough.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,390, down 79 (-1.77%), High: 4,452, Low: 4,379, Volume: 1.44m
BE11:44am

Here comes Deutsche to talk us through the data.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Bristol Myers Squib yesterday disclosed that it does not plan to seek an early accelerated approval of its Opdivo/Yervoy combination in 1L lung cancer based on an analysis of available data. We expect some investors to read this negatively for the prospects of AZN’s similar durvalumab/tremelimumab combination in the MYSTIC study. However, we disagree with this view. We have argued that it is highly unlikely that BMS would be able to file early based on Phase II data given current regulatory requirements for accelerated approval. We therefore see the decision as unsurprising and that it is likely to predominantly reflect the extremely high hurdle to a regulatory filing at this stage, when no randomised data comparing to current standard-of-care is available. As such, this does not diminish our optimism over the outcome of AZN’s MYSTIC trial and the potential of its immuno-oncology portfolio.

BE11:45am

As a reminder, BMS is conducting a randomised Phase III trial of its Opdivo/Yervoy combination in 1L lung cancer (CheckMate-227) with data officially due in 1H 2018. However, it had suggested the possibility of an early filing based on its Phase II trials (CheckMate-012 and CheckMate-568). This is unusual given that current regulatory requirements for early approvals require there to be an unmet need (no available therapy) or for evidence of superior efficacy/safety to established therapy. Given that neither of BMS’s Phase II trials includes a comparison to established standard-of-care therapy, we struggle to see how it can have generated data to meet this requirement in a broad 1L patient population.

BE11:46am

We expect many investors to become concerned that BMS’ decision reflects disappointing data from the ongoing CheckMate-568 study, which could diminish enthusiasm for dual checkpoint inhibition use in 1L lung cancer. While we accept that the decision could reflect that the data is not so substantially impressive as to justify a filing that seems to go against standard regulatory requirements, we believe this more than likely simply reflects the very high hurdle for a filing in these circumstances. As such, this does not diminish our optimism over AZN’s similar durvalumab/tremelimumab combination. In addition, we remind investors that recent trial amendments to the MYSTIC study should significantly increase its chances of having a fileable package in 1L lung cancer, when data reports in mid 2017

The suppliers involved, which operated a joint venture which saw them both provide services and products under the Micronclean brand, are:

- Micronclean Limited, formerly known as Fenland Laundries Limited (Fenland); and

- Berendsen Cleanroom Services Limited, formerly known as Micronclean (Newbury) Limited (Berendsen Newbury).

PM11:51am

The CMA provisionally finds that under the market-sharing arrangement, Fenland served customers in an area north of a line broadly between London and Anglesey, whilst Berendsen Newbury served customers located south of that line. Certain other customers were allegedly divided up between the parties based on the nature of their business or the product or service they required. The alleged arrangement prevented each company from supplying customers which were located outside the company's designated area and/or certain types of customers.
